19772120.review:
This is probably the first spoopy game I've played since the first Amnesia.

You randomly get 1 of 3 monsters from which to escape on a massive ship. There are 3 possible exits, but which one you use can depend on which monster you have, or which parts you can find to get your exit in working condition.

The map RNG is similar to Rogue Legacy, where the general areas are the same, but the halls and rooms and items within them can be in completely different configurations. Even the cargo hold has a random layout of open containers to search through, which is different (and tense!) every time you search through them, and try not to get stuck in a dead end with the monster on your back.

There's currently no save system, so depending on how safe you play, games can last up to at least an hour. Usually much shorter thanks to the monster, heh.

There aren't really weapons to kill the monster, just stall them briefly so that you can get away or complete objectives. Each monster has their special traits, each requiring different tactics to deal with.

The monsters don't appear to be able to magically home in on you all the time, at least if you haven't been spotted lately, however they have an annoying tendancy to rubberband. The monsters seem to have some kind of leash where, even if you bait them all the way to the opposite side of the ship, and not get spotted, they seem to magically make their way back to your side of the ship (without searching rooms in their area first) within a minute or 2.

The exits themselves can be pretty tense, as you usually have to assemble or operate some equipment, and balance how much work you do against how much noise you can make before the monster catches up.

I didn't really notice any bugs or crashes during my playthrough, except one time where a monster got stuck after breaking a radio.

Overall I enjoyed this quite a bit. The RNG keeps the game from getting predictable, and every room is a tense moment where you're trying to quickly look for key items and plan your next move, and not turn into a monster chewtoy.

19744467.review:
[h1]Das Spiel[/h1]
Wir wachen allein auf einem Containerschiff auf. In der hintersten Ecke hat uns offenbar ein Kamerad versteckt, vor dem was da noch auf dem Schiff lauert. Wie wir schnell herausfinden, sind wir nicht allein. Jeweils eines von drei Monstern befindet sich mit uns auf dem Schiff. Die Räume im Schiff sind jede Runde neu angeordnet, so dass es immer wieder auf neue spannend wird. Da auf dem Schiff zu bleiben keine Option ist, zumindest nicht, wenn wir überleben wollen, müssen wir nach einer geeigneten Fluchtmöglichkeit suchen. Wir haben dabei die Wahl mit dem Rettungsboot, einem Hubschrauber oder dem Tauchboot zu entkommen. Für jede Fluchtmöglichkeit sind ein paar Teile zu finden, die mehr oder minder zufällig an Bord zu finden sind. Ist die Flucht geglückt, wird man mit einer Endsequenz belohnt und kann einen neuen Versuch wagen und sich selbst Challenges stellen.

[h1]Meine Meinung[/h1]
Ich spiele Monstrum jetzt bereits seit gut 100 Stunden und habe in Kürze ebensoviele Folgen Let's Play Monstrum auf YouTube. Das interessante dabei ist, dass das Spiel dennoch immer wieder Spaß macht und mich und die Zuschauer fesselt. Die Monster haben alle Ihre Eigenarten, die man nach einiger Zeit zwar kennt und einzuschätzen weiss, was dem Spielspaß aber überhaupt nicht schadet. Zu Halloween haben sich die Entwickler einen schönen Spaß erlaubt und die Monster mit Kürbisköpfen versehen und das Schiff dekoriert. Solche Spielereien wirken vielleicht klein, bringen aber viel Spaß ins Spiel.

[h1]Perfomance[/h1]
Bei all dem Lob darf jedoch ein kleiner Makel nicht fehlen. Die Performance des Spiels list leider nicht immer das, was man aus dem Spiel herausholen könnte. Es scheint einige Seeds der Spielwelt zu geben, welche die Performance in den Keller ziehen. Vielleicht wird hier aber ja noch nachgebessert.

[h1]Fazit[/h1]
Alles in allem auf jeden Fall ein gelungenes Spiel und für mich und meine Abonnenten ein absolutes Muss bei fast jedem Livestream. Ich hoffe, dass weiterhin an dem Spiel gearbeitet wird und wir uns als Monstrum Community noch auf viele Stunden Spielspaß und tolle Neuerungen gefasst machen können. Potential hat das Spiel genug. Anregungen hierfür wären zum Beispiel ein Multiplayer Modus oder aber die Auswahl des Schwierigkeitsgrades, in dem man sich mehrere Monster auf den Hals laden kann. Aber ich warte an dieser Stelle einfach mal gespannt, was die Entwickler noch für uns bereit halten.

Monstrum is a lot like the classic Groundhog Day, only if Bill Murray was waking up on an abandoned ship out in the ocean and was hunted by monsters. And the ship kept changing its layout in such a way you'd swear it was non-euclidean when below decks.

- Wake up
- Get Flashlight
- Wander around
- Alert monster
- Try to hide
- Get found
- Die horribly

- Wake up
- Get flashlight...

The game really gives you no feeling of hope... Without that thought that you might survive, it sucks any sort of investment I have into faceless guy take 17. I went from trying to stealth and carefully manage the items I had to just sprinting to try and uncover more of the ship before eventually being found and being ripped in half.

Unless you're into your terror turning into tedium, I can't recommend Monstrum.

19408001.review:
Greetings fellow gamers! This is Gamer Guy (In a Suit) from the Echo Army YouTube channel! Today I am bringing you a review of the Survival Horror game, Monstrum. Monstrum was released on Steam back on May 20, 2015 by Publisher/Developer Team Junkfish.

(NOTE: This was a review from a game in my own Steam library, it was NOT provided by the Developer and/or Publisher)

Video Review: 

https://youtu.be/ZOe6aSNpwP4	

The "Too Long, Didn't Watch" Review:

Great entry in the genre. Blend of Rogue-like and First-Person Horror is fantastic. 
4/5 A bit pricey, but solid. Worth the $.

The "Meat & Potatoes" Review:

Monstrum is what happens when you take the First Person Survival Horror thing, do it right, then combine it with some cool rogue-like elements. Team Junkfish has really nailed it here. The ship you appear to be stuck in gets randomly generated for every play-through. There are some similarities of course, but it is definitely different each time. The best part of this mechanic though is the antagonists themselves. See, each time you restart this game, it could be one of 3 different monster-types trying to get you. Obviously, until you get to exploring, you have no way of knowing which and this could change your approach. THe gameplay is very easy and familiar to this type of game. Walk around, hide in cabinets/lockers when needed, run for your life occasionally, find stuff to solve puzzles (in the form of finding and managing an escape) and get the hell of this boat.   If you enjoy the horror genre in PC gaming these days, it really doesn't get much better. The visuals are great, the sounds are fantastic, the atmosphere is superb. It's a touch pricey, but well worth it. There is a ton of replayability here. A gem among the numerous horror games out there. Do not let Monstrum pass you by. 4/5.

Happy Gaming!!!

19339392.review:
I rarely play these kinds of Horror games, simply because I'm a huge baby.. I jumped into this not knowing really anything and I have to say that I'm quite unsure wether to recommend or not recommend this game.

The "Story" ís pretty generic and almost nonexistent.
Game starts with you, the player, waking up in a spooky, abandoned cargo ship.
Once you realize that the ship is inhabited by some weird monsters straight from some Sci-Fi flick, you try to find your way out of the ship. 

The gameplay basically works like the good ol' "Slender: The Eight Pages", you try to collect items from broken vehicles of three options, Helicopter, Submarine and Life Raft.. Once you've fixed up one of these vehicles mentioned before, you survive and the game's over.

It sounds pretty dull doesn't it ? In the games defense I'd like to state that the AI for these monsters is quite amazing. There's 3 different kind of monsters and each time you start a new game or die, the monster might be a different one.. Same goes with the map, you're in a similar kind of cargo ship but the rooms are placed differently etc. It's all meant to give the game some replay value and giving you a feel that there's something new you haven't experienced yet.

..Anyway, back to the monsters. Each monster works quite differently, The Brute is a massive, glowy fire monster that can smash through doors and is the fastest monster out of those three. Then there's The Fiend who floats around hunting for the player, he can also warp from place to place, use telekinetic powers on the player slowing him down etc. and is the most intelligent monster of the three.
And for last there's The Hunter, skinny, tall and skeletal figure who looks like a god*amn jellyfish. He hunts for the player using the ventilation shafts to his advantage, he can also lay eggs that he can burst out from to ambush the player.

Overall as you can see the monsters all work and look very different from each other. The devs did a fine work on them.
To add one more pro in the games defense I'd like to say that the sound design is absolutely phenomenal.. As I was hiding in a closet from The Brute I could hear him walking around, stomping his feet against the metallic floor. The sound of him roaring and the stomping sound caused by his walking sent shivers down my spine.

I have to say though, despite all these cool mechanics, the game does feel like it could've used more content. 
There's just not enough to do.. I've played it for 2 hours and I already feel like I've done everything there is to do.
Sure you can collect logs and notes but that'll only keep you busy for a while. There just isn't enough replay value despite there being all the different monsters and map changing every time you start again.. It still feels the same. 
The objective is exactly the same and I wish there was more to do. 

Playing with a controller was also quite painful, mentally I mean.. looking around with the thumbsticks is very clunky.
I personally recommend playing with mouse & keyboard. 
I also got stuck running away from these monstrosities quite often, which was quite the annoyance.

Taking the price of the game into account I think it's a pretty good deal especially if you're getting it on sale.
If you're looking for a good horror game with a story, this isn't the game for you.. 
But if you love jumpscares and the Slender like games then this definitely is the one for you. 
It's certainly one of the better Indie horror titles here on Steam!

I'd suggest you pick it up if you're in the mood to wet your pants and you find it on sale.

I rate : [spoiler]5.75 / 10.00[/spoiler]

my god...

The fear rating on this is 9/10 and that's saying something, since I basically eat horror games for breakfast. It does its job really well, and I have a feeling it will scare players who legit try not to get scared. I have not had my heart pumping like this in a long time. the fear for me turns up to 12/10 when you use the oculus rift. I've never shook so hard in my life. you can imagine why. 

the game play is solid. and I've never felt this much freedom in a horror game of this style, even more so than Outlast or Alien Isolation. Because you can go ANYWHERE you want on the ship, which ramps up the horror even more cause you feel like it REALLY IS up to you to go and figure out how to save yourself from the situation. no hand holding, other than with helping understand how to repair something (via shopping list to fix a submarine for e.g.). your own plans, your own decision, your own fault for getting what you need to get and failing to do so from monsters with there own plans as well.

Seriously, the monsters are really smart and I can tell by the way they behave. If there are multiple places that I could be hiding, they'll just skim through all the rooms without checking under beds and stuff to save time and to try and keep me from running from room to room. And if they have a really good idea of where you are, they'll stick around in your room for a long, long time until they find you or give up. they're not there to be spooky, they are legit trying to eat your face to the best of their abilities. It gives you a true sense of being hunted, one which few horror games have achieved.

there tends to be a bug or two, but they are very rare and will never break game-play. In fact none of the bugs revolve around the player, so you'll never die a cheap buggy death. any bugs I've found revolve around the monsters, which is good cause you'll need all the help you can get :P

Each monster has its own strengths and weaknesses, but no matter how well you know the monster, it can still catch you completely off guard. Remember, they are SMART. I remember a monster chased me down the side of the ship on the top deck, and I went into a red locker on the port side. I saw it rush past my locker. It stopped at the corner up ahead, sensing that it wasn't chasing a running target any more. so it began retracing its steps, trying to figure out where I went. it went back and forth in front of my locker. and each pass it went slower and slower and slower. I knew that one of those passes will result in it figuring out that I was right beside it the whole time. and I was shitting myself with the realization. I ran the moment it did another pass on my locker, but even though I lost it, I was still shaking.

get the fucking game. it's a real gem amongst the 2015 ocean of "scary" game wannabe's.

18806331.review:
Super fun concept. Escape from a broken down freighter while a killer monster hunts you down. Random level generation is a double-edged sword, however.

In reality, you have to scour each and every room for components to help assemble your escape vessel. There is almost no rhyme or reason to item placement; and since levels are random each time you start up, you have to stip search the ENTIRE ship. You can search drawers and hide in cabinets, but you'll find that both are kind of pointless at times. Sometimes they'll really jerk you around and hide an item under shelving/furniture. 

Notes do not provide clues as to where these items are located, but they do give some backstory into the crew members and how they perished. With 3 monsters, I expected the story to change each time and at least tell me which monster was going to torment me; the story is simply vague enough to be apllied to all three at once: therefore notes you collected from previous runs will be saved (which gets kind of confusing).

The monsters are great. They will relentlessly hunt you down. I don't really care if they just "spawn near you" since that's exactly what Amnesia: The Dark Descent did, my problem is that for a game that is supposed to be replayable... you can't really do much other than run and hide. Monsters have almost no problem getting through locked/shut doors. You can use a fire extinguisher to stun them. Great... (Trapping, killing, or removing the monster from the ship would be fun as hell)

TL;DR
Good fun every now and then, but gets stale pretty fast.

18568912.review:
Monstrum is a First Person, Roguelike, Action Horror game made by Team Junkfish... And my most favorite horror game ever.
Well, No time to loiter, let's get into this!

Most of the aesthetic comes from the game taking place on a Cargo Freighter; The Freighter is beautifully crafted and screams atmosphere at every corner and in every room you'll enter, and every room looks like something fitted on a ship, from the wooden walls, curtains and tables, cups, books and several other items on shelves and in drawers, to the lighting and dust and muck stained windows which give almost every residential area in Monstrum a used and almost cozy look...
despite it clearly being a horror game.

The Hallways and Industrial area's on the ship are unnerving and creepy, especially when you consider there is a monster of true nightmares walking around the same halls as you.

Speaking of monsters, i'll introduce you to them:
[The Brute]: Basically the face of the game, a gianormous, molded beast which appears to be constructed of a molten substance, and has magma flowing trough it's head (and possibly the rest of it's body), you'll be able to notice it by it's constant groaning and heavy footsteps, thundering trough the deserted and dusty hallways of the ship.

[The Hunte]r: The game's Rogue class monster. It's able to traverse the vast area's of the ship trough the ventilation shafts located among the walls of the residential area, and the ceiling and ground of the lower levels of the freighter. It has the ability to "spawn" egg sacs and hide in some of them, disturbing these sacs will spawn it near you, in the egg sacs and sometimes on the edge of the ship (if placed near the railings) prompting it to crawl up the hull, giving you a small window of time to start fleeing for your life.

[The Fiend]: An odd anomaly, with a skeletal appearance and an ability to telepathically "close" doorways that seems to be able to float. He is announced by a continous flikkering of lighting when he's in the vicinity, if you are in an area without lighting, shining your flashlight for a moment and seeing if it flikkers will give away it's presence.

During every playtrough a random monster is chose to hunt you trough the ship, making every playtrough different, and that's not the only difference you'll notice during every game.

The ship's enterior is entirely randomly generated, with exceptions for the floors, and certain rooms, for instance: the Boiler room, and the Bridge. as well as a randomized layout, you'll have a pletera of escape routes, and i won't spoil them.

During your gameplay experience you'll find notes and audio recordings, most of which explain the story that happened on the ship.

During the game you'll have to hide from the monster, using the ship's many compartements, rooms, lockers, tables and the darkness to conceal yourself from it.

But the monster isn't the only threat on the ship. The Security system is still active, causing the camera's on the ship to announce any unwanted visitors with a loud noise, which, of course, draws the monster to that camera. Luckily you can duct-tape camera's to prevent them from going off. There's also a vast amount of steam vents located around the ship's lower levels.

TL;DR
Monstrum is a phenomenal survival horror game that will give you a constant feeling of dread and paranoia as you walk trough hallways, cargo area's and rooms, long sweeped clean of any living being by the monster. You'll fear it, and you'll love it.

All in all, Monstrum is an amazing experience, and something you HAVE to play.

Have fun.
-Cronix

18458226.review:
Where to begin with Monstrum? 

First, let's talk about the VR implementation. It is damn solid. The game runs beautifully in VR, and looks great too. They also provide a little dial around you that tells you where you're character is oriented, and where you're looking with the headset. It's a good indicator for when you need to reset the headset orientation. 

In fact, the VR is TOO well done. While playing with my Oculus Rift, I had never actually had pure terror instilled in me by a game before, and Monstrum did just that. I was cowering underneath a table, listening to the brute stomp around looking for me. Scariest gaming experience to date.

Now let's look at the game's mechanics as a horror game. The thing they do right, is give you a goal right when you start. There's nothing I hate more than wandering around in a horror game not knowing what the hell I'm doing. What's the point if I don't have something to work for? And this goal actually adds a lot to the horror element. It gives the player a much greater sense of survival and wanting to live, making the game even more terrifying. The noise mechanic is also a pretty big staple of horror games, but for a reason, it works. It gives the player hope that they have a chance of escape in a bad situation. 

Basically, the game gives the player just enough ability to survive, while keeping the terror meter cranked on high. 

10/10 would crap my pants again.

The games objective is to escape the ship where you have woken up and have no memory of how you got there. There are 3 escape routes, which are the helicopter, the submarine and the life raft.
To be able to escape the ship from any of these escape routes, you must first find items and prepare the escape routes to succesfully escape.

Monstrum is very well made, but needs some minor bug fixing, some more updates and possibly a new monster, story mode, or multiplayer mode. That would be awesome!

17869869.review:
FULL review below
Revised per updates

+ Randomly generated levels
+ Beautifully atmospheric
+ Great sound
+ Unsettling AI behavior

- Not enough monsters (This is such a brilliant concept. I wish it had a tad more variety) this mainly affects replayability.

= Permadeath


FULL REVIEW:

Figured I'd go ahead and write a real review for this game, as this is exactly what it deserves.

17.99? Please... If it had just a bit more content then honestly, with the brilliant concept that this games manages to float around possessing, sprinkling its magical little trail of blood curdling pixie dust. Praise to this indie dev team as they carve a spot in my favs collection. I admit after playing for a few hours I am not screaming as often, but still. I shouldn’t be screaming at all, yet here we are. Complaints from the roommates late at night get old, but I suppose that is either the fault of mine for buying this game, or team Junkfish for creating such a marvelous gem of pure adrenaline. Not fueled by pumping bullets, by just simply by the fear of getting caught.

You explore an abandoned hunk of metal death floating god knows where in the middle of the ocean. Peruse the ship in search of vital pieces of equipment, to help fuel the frantic struggle to your escape or your demise. Something has broken from its metal prison container in the cargo bay, and is now hungry and P' offed. And you are the tastiest thing around. But I mean who wouldn’t be super upset after cutting a deep gash in your bumpy monster knuckle. Repeatedly slamming it into the sharp edge of an industrial shipping container, prying the torn metal edges of the hole, raging to get out like a little newborn baby having a tantrum in its crib. This baby is ready to destroy the crib and eat all of the furniture. Taste like wood, screw it. Plus one for America and doing whatever the eff you want. Plus it's procedural, so you’ll never know which hall to turn down, despite some of the major areas of the ship remaining static. Which in this case didn't bother me at all. There being several methods of departure from the horrible monstrosity aboard the ghostly vessel of Monstrum, you will often find pieces that contribute to the endgame in some manner but seldom do you find the pieces relevant to your current attempt right away. Each method requires different items. On the flip side there are also several non essentials to pick up, my favorite being the old radio. DO NOT MAKE THE SAME STUPID MISTAKE IT'S NOT WORTH IT MAN, IT"S NOT WORTH IT. All I wanted..... was to not be sad. All I wanted was to shake my booty, like I'm the only girl in the world. All I wanted...  was some tunes man.... and all I got, was stomping and shouting and then eventually screaming (from me) as I charge down the hall still to be caught by the foot and smashed anyways. Sigh. Navigate through doors and pitch black stairwells (batteries in your torch do NOT lasting long btw). Sprint through hallways as the ocean waves crash outside, sneak by security (or don’t lol), and hide in lockers or under desks/beds. Usually because you are about to have your face ripped off by one of the multiple creatures you may encounter, although one at a time.  I’ve gotten in the habit of leaving a few locker doors open to avoid those few precious seconds as I run around a corner and fumble with my buttons long enough to slam the locker shut before the beast sees me. Never feel safe though, dont be fooled. The number of times I snickered as the beast slowly crept by my locker door or paced by the bed I was cowering under, still chuckling once I assumed I had achieved victory, the suave super slick genius that I most defin ONLY TO HAVE MY SENTENCE AND HAPPY TIME INTERUPTED BY THE SOUNDS OF MY SCREAMS as I am dragged out from under the bed like a parent preparing their child for a spanking. A spanking made of pain and terror and ripping your guts out. Rude, but hey. The rush is great. Sprinting isn't always the key though, there is quite a bit to trip on or run into and it WILL be a factor of life and death, if you run into any of these environmental "traps" at the wrong time. So watch your footing, or you'll lose a foot. And everything else. Including your face, as stated.

The Visuals. Pretty good. Not a diamond in the rough type deal but definitely a pretty game. If anything, it’s very good at being dark and dismal. Oh yeah and depressing. Everyone is dead and you’re not too far behind. That fiery orange glow illuminating from between the jaws of the Brute as it slowly bleeds into the darkness of an upcoming stairwell, is horrifying. The game is literally filled when omens from the jump and has no problem letting you know what will be hunting, and eventually murdering you. In this fashion, you have a chance to plan your strategy, unless you are a first timer. In this case. Listen to this one piece of advice. DO NOT RESEARCH OR WATCH CONTENT INVOLVING THIS GAME. Believe me when I say if you go into this floating slice of hell with no prior knowledge, I can guarantee the initial scares are almost worth the price alone. The eggs left around by you know who are also quiet unsettling I would like to add. But if your eyes don’t yank your guts into a shriek then the audio will.

This game..... Has BRILLIANT audio design, that will leave you flailing your arms as you jump from your seat and proceed to exit the room. And I say that whole heartedly. The running sequences blare what can only remind me of the gut wrenching metallic squeals of machinery emitted from my speakers during any of my romps through the universes of Silent Hill. But that’s me personally. Sounds of rusty metal clamoring and rattling loudly, just before an abrupt hiss of steam shoots from a crack and burns hot superheated water vapor into your eyeballs, forcing you to the ground at the WORST possible moment. Slamming of doors and lockers and the BLOOD curdling cry of the security system alarm.

My god. 

The sirens on this ship. I swear they were manufactured for a max security prison with the intention of bursting the inmate’s eardrums long before they could complete an attempt at escape. I keep a set of q-tips and tissue on my desk at all times to stop the bleeding. The screams and shrieks of the on-board menace startle me sometimes even more than the effing thing jumping right in my face, which also happens... In front of all my friends.... On my birthday.... LIVE on stream. <_< Right when I thought I was safe the game’s like well nope screw you. But this is what I love. If you want to poo yourself turn the volume up and flip the lights off. This is the soundtrack I can expect someone to hear as they enter the gates of hell.

So, in conclusion. No, this game is not perfect. No, it’s not the scariest game on earth, but that is due to the sole reason, that eventually once something is experienced enough, you just simply know what to expect. But f**k does this game come close. The combination of concept, video and audio are a delightful mixture that bubbles in a cauldron until all the fumes and vapors suffocate everyone in the room. A little girl picks up her box of brownie mix and stares at it puzzled, then glances once more at her family now laying limp on the floor. She shrugs and retreats up to her room, hops on the computer, fires up a round of Monstrum, and has a heart attack several minutes later.  


*Little girl survives by the way. Turns out I was mistaken and she just passed out from fear. But still

[h1]Fluff Review:[/h1]

Monstrum is a scary game. The atmosphere is unsettling, the developers really made the game look like you are on an old abandoned boat. Everything feels scary. The rooms: old and decrepit, the sound of the doors opening and closing: scary, and the monsters that chase you: terrifying. The game is randomly generated, so there is no way to build off of your old experience. The game allows you to pick from three endings, depending on how you try to escape. Each time you start a new game, you get 1 of the three monsters, no telling which one. Its a very hardcore game. I literally, at 26 hours, just beat the game a single time. The lowest dicount for the game is 45% off asking price, which is more than fair. I would have gladly purchased the game full price. The GTD (Game to Dollar) Ratio that I got was 1 to $0.70. Imagine dropping a measly three quarters to play this well crafted game for an hour. In this game, I encountered no bugs whatsoever, and everything seems extremly well put together.

This game is incredible, and one of the best indie horror games ive ever seen. Pros and Cons?

Pros
-------
Very good AI.
Incredibly scary
Huge map
Loads of hiding locations, but none of them are 100% safe
Lots of items
Detail put into the escape routes (Life raft, helicopter, submarine)
Good audio
Nice graphics, while maintaining good fps
(Well optimized)

Not easy to beat either
Well thought out and detailed monsters, all with their own strengths and weaknesses
Great enviroment and atmosphere
Interactive enviroment (can flush toilets, move furniture, open drawers, ect)
Fair priced for its great quality

Great soundtrack

Cons

Security cam monitors are copy and pasted images

The escape pics could be a lot cooler if it were a video, and not just pics, but a step up from before atleast
The ocean looks a little wierd

17112982.review:
[b]Персональный рейтинг - 7,5 из 10[/b]

Ночь. Огромный грузовой корабль. Пропавшие моряки. Обрывки воспоминаний, что записаны на тетрадных страницах в клетку, раскиданы тут и там. Обязательный полумрак. Монстр, который всегда рядом. Схватка один на один в декорациях видавшего виды контейнеровоза с темной историей. Один беззащитный игрок против чудища. Честный бой посреди джунглей из стальных труб, бесконечных коридоров, уютных, хотя и скромных, кают исчезнувшего экипажа и тонн металла. Посреди океана. Некуда бежать. На что уповать? На смекалку, быстрые ноги, реакцию, умение прятаться и не шуметь. И, конечно же, на удачу.

Без удачи тут ловить нечего. Моряк всегда должен быть готов к трудностям. Шторм, качка, замкнутые пространства. А что если все сразу и черт знает что впридачу! Мы не знаем, как мы оказались на этой полуржавой посудине. Но знаем одно - надо выбраться отсюда.

С началом каждого нового забега в Monstrum мы оказываемся в одном из нескольких случайных укрытий где-то во чреве корабля-исполина. Задача - сбежать с судна любым из трех доступных способов. Чтобы мы не скучали, компанию нам составит один из троицы монстров, случайным образом выбираемый игрой. Он - главная звезда всего шоу. Непредсказуемый, коварный и невероятно опасный. До своего коллеги из Alien: Isolation ему, разумеется, еще очень далеко, но не стоит недооценивать здешних обитателей из страны кошмаров. 

Где-то наверху я упомянул честный бой. Ладно, признаюсь, не совсем честный. Монстр всегда знает, где вы. Даже если, случайно попавшись на глаза чудовищу, вы броситесь наутек и по-спринтерски пронесетесь от нижней палубы до верхней (на корабле их, к слову, восемь), то знайте, что буквально через 30-40 секунд коварная тварь будет колобродить где-то поблизости. Перед разработчиками стояла задача - поддерживать напряжение всеми доступными способами. То пар из дырявых труб на нижних палубах больно ударит в нос, играя на нервах мерзко-шипящим звуком. То топот страхолюдины где-то за дверью заставит съежиться и невольно осмотреться по сторонам. Тут практически негде чувствовать себя в безопасности. То есть вы можете, конечно, сидеть в самой первой локации до посинения, но это будут минуты, потраченные впустую. Игра вообще всячески подталкивает рисковать и ходить по краю, балансировать, рискуя попасться в лапы к чудищу, но получить надежду на спасение из плавучего ада, либо прятаться под кроватью в одной из кают и остаться ни с чем, не приблизившись к цели ни на йоту. Хотите перехитрить монстра - научитесь преодолевать страх. Как в любой классической истории - ценные вещи всегда непросто достать и те, как правило, охраняются могучими стражами. Здесь такой страж лишь один, но вам и его хватит за глаза.

В целях реализации дерзкого побега с проклятого корабля нам необходимы предметы, без которых побег будет невозможен. Учитывая, что игра включает в себя элементы rogue-like, то таковые разбросаны по всему кораблю и могут находиться где угодно. Нам в прямом смысле надлежит обшарить каждый угол, ведь никогда не знаешь, где может скрываться искомая вещица. Некоторые особо везучие сухопутные крысы умудрялись пройти игру за 5 минут - предметы для побега генерировались буквально в соседних комнатах. Но не думайте, что вы будете настолько же удачливы.

Выглядит Monstrum симпатично. Интерьеры сухогруза выполнены аутентично и с должным тщанием. Это, кстати, один из сильнейших аспектов игры - трудно не поверить, что находишься где-то внутри огромного корабля - настолько аккуратно проработаны его пусть и по-спартански строгие, но одновременно пугающие коридоры и лестничные проемы. К звуку претензий никаких. Рев охочих до вашего окорока тварей, гул механизмов, щелчки переключателей. Когда тварь выбивает дверь, грохот закладывает уши. Это высший комплимент местному звуковому оформлению. 

Как полагается любой подобной инди-игре, оптимизация выполнена на троечку. Периодически происходят беспричинные падения счетчика кадров до преступных значений, хотя, стоит отдать должное, игра не даром провалялась в "Раннем доступе" значительное время - за все время игры не было ни одного вылета, зависания и ни разу не выскакивала критическая ошибка.

Глупо говорить, но, если хотите испытать полную гамму удивительных ощущений от игры в Monstrum, то не стоит играть в нее днем, попивая чай с вареньем. Только ночью, в темной комнате, в наушниках. 

Отдать швартовы! Следующая остановка - Монструм.

17111409.review:
Единственный хоррор в который  я играл , и понял что это не моё. Просто опишу эту игру.


Вы появляетесь на корабле (либо в мастерской, либо в душевой). Естественно, у вас амнезия, и естественно, вам придётся узнавать что случилось путём записок, разбросанных по всему кораблю. Корабль каждый раз генерируется рандомно, и каждый раз вы будете встречать одного из трёх монстров (иногда 2-ух). 16923620.review:
[h1]What is Monstrum?[/h1]
Monstrum is a first person survival-horror expierence with random generated maps.

[h1]What is the point of the game?[/h1]
You are the only person alive on a ship somewhere in the ocean and you have to escape this ship in order to beat the game. You can escape when you found all items needed for a escape route.

[h1]What makes Monstrum so special?[/h1]
The fact that the maps are all random generated and that you can escape via different methods is pretty well thought. Also the game gives you more shocking moments then actual "horror" moments I would say, but that is in a positive way which encourages you to play even more and more carefully.

[h1]What is not so good about Monstrum?[/h1]
Even though the shock moments will stay, if you played through the game a few times it gets a little bit repetitive or easier I should say. There is no difficulty bar, just different monster which may can be seen as different difficulties.
Furthermore I don't know if the game is going to be updated anymore since it's out of Early Access.

[h1]Should I buy Monstrum?[/h1]
If you are into shocker and a bit of survival and dont throw away the computer every time you die (because you have to start from scratch), then Monstrum will get you some good moments with it.
14.99€ is a fair price for the game.

If you are still unsure about buying the game, watch some videos on YouTube and decide for yourself. You should not get yourself too spoiled.

Monstrum is a terrifying game. Absolutely nowhere on this ship is safe, and the monster pursuing you could emerge at any time. The randomly generated ship is claustrophobic and disorienting, which helps with the sense of isolation that the game goes for. The only real problem I have with the game is the price--it's a rather shallow game, with no story and anywhere between 5 and 40 minutes per playthrough. Though the replay value IS high, I really wouldn't consider this a game worth the almost twenty dollar price it asks for; I'd say it's worth around the Summer sale value of ten dollars.
Still, though, a great indie game worth checking out if you plan on replaying it.

16695011.review:
https://youtu.be/IU_TtM0a2pQ

You wake up alone in a ship filled with monsters. What happened is a mystery, but one thing is certain, you got to get out before you get killed. You can escape through a liferaft, a submarine or a helicopter. But first you have to gather the right tools and items to fix them. And that’s where the problem starts, since they’re randomly scattered around the ship. There is no save point, so if a monster kills you, you’ll start from scratch. 

And you will die. Monsters get attracted by noises you make or other actions. But that means you might be able to trick them… if you’re smart. But hiding around in lockers or under furniture will be your main getaway. When everything else fails, you run. But be careful, since the ship is falling to pieces and you might stupidly die in one of it’s traps. As you explore your surroundings, you’ll find notes with tips and small revelations of what happened.

The main objective this game needed to accomplish is to be scary. And it was… for a while. The environment has a spooky feel and the “hide-and-seek” dynamic does get the blood pumping. But it lacks on ambient sounds to make you more paranoid and immersed. But the biggest flaw is, after some plays, you catch on the monsters’ patterns and it becomes tedious. What should be a question of attention and skill, becomes more a question of repetition and random luck.

16653844.review:
Monstrum is one of the greatest games in the horror genre.

The setting gives a feeling of isolation, with random generation always providing a level of challenge and unfamiliarity. The silence makes every noise seem alarmingly loud, and every step you worry will reveal your location.

Gameplay wise, this game is awesome. There are three different monsters, each with their own behaviors and abilities. When you start a game, you will be on the edge of your seat waiting for and dreading the first apparence of the monster. You have three ways to get off the ship, and every game the ship is generated differently so you never know where you can run and hide until you have explored it again.

The monster behavior in this game is fantastic. I especially love that you get one hit killed if you get directly caught by a monster, it makes it far more frightening than having a creature do the same clumsy animation 3 or 4 times to kill you.

The difficult adds to the intensity. It is beatable, but it is not easy. You know you can escape the monster, but you know you likely won't. Every playthrough is a bitch.

There are also little mechanics peppered throughout the game that you need to discover on your own so I will not talk about them. Winning the game usually takes a bit more than running and hiding.

TL;DR

This game will be so intense that you hardly want to play it. So, if you want an truly good horror experience, but this game!

16653395.review:
[h1] Monstrum [/h1]
[i] Monstrum ne vaut pas son prix tant il est amateur. Encore un jeu qui doit sa popularité à des youtubeur hystériques. Pensez plutôt à investir dans Outlast ou Alien Isolation quand ils seront soldés. Si vous voulez tenter l'aventure, achetez le bradé à 5€ pour se marrer quelques heures. [/i]

[h1] J'aime [/h1]

- Une ambiance opressante.
- Les graphismes sont propres pour une production indépendante. Enfin c'est pas la claque graphique non plus.
- Contenu généré aléatoirement, impossible de connaitre le plan du  bateau par coeur.
- Le design des monstres est bien réussis, surtout la brute et son halo de lumière incandescente.
- Gameplay type Rogue like assez motivant. J'aurais quand même aimé une sauvegarde auto optionelle.

[h1] J'aime pas [/h1]

- Animations à revoir, comme le briquet qui s'allume sans bouger le pouce.
- Gameplay Frustrant. Problèmes de colisions, difficulté à ramasser certains objets.
- Trop punitif et injuste.
- Le monstre se retrouve toujours dans la partie du bateau où vous êtes. C'est à dire que vous débarquez sur tel pont. Vous aurez quelques minutes avant qu'il débarque. Ce qui a tendance à stoper net votre recherche dans cette zone étant donné que la brute et le demon sont hyperactifs et bougent sans arrêt.
- L'insecte quand à lui sortira d'une gaine à un moment aléatoire sans que vous ne fassiez aucun bruit. Biensur il choisira la ventilation qui est juste à côté de vous.
- Le monstre est programmé pour faire semblant de ne pas savoir où vous êtes, jusqu'à ce que vous fassiez quelque chose qui trahisse votre position, comme du bruit par exemple.
- On se rend assez vite compte que cette difficulté  élevée cache un gros manque de contenu. les couloirs se ressemblent tous, peu de variation dans les items. Il ne faut pas longtemps pour assembler le plan d'évasion.
- L'histoire est inexistante si ce n'est pour les petits messages disséminés ici et là. Pas vraiment intéréssants et très générique pour s'adapter à n'importe laquelle des 3 créatures.
- Le pire dans tout ça c'est que quand vous avez enfin terminé la partie et quitté le bateau. Vous aurez le droit à un pauvre diaporama en noir et blanc. Même pas quelques éléments d'histoires pour éclaircir le truc.

[h1] Mention honorable [/h1]
- La vapeur tueuse 
- Les cameras fonctionnant avec un systeme de sécurité éteint.

Ужасная, просто ужасная игра! В нее невозможно играть! Это...это безумие, самое что ни на есть безумие! Это кошмарная игра, воплощение ужаса и страха! Здесь не пугают скриммерами, не пугают выпрыгивающими из за угла монстрами или другими банальными средствами запугивания. Здесь пугают атмосферой, атмосферой безнадеги и одиночества...

[h1]Геймплей:[/h1]
Геймплей сам по себе банален и сводится к блужданию по грузовому кораблю и его внутренностям, состоящим мз нескольких, а точнее семи, палуб, которые генерируются каждый раз случайным образом. В процессе блуждания задачей игрока является поиск одного из трех средств побега с кораблся и необходимых запчастей, с помощью которых данный помег можно будет осуществить. На пути у игрока станет один из трех видов монстров, который будет вам мешать. Каждый монстр индивидуален, имеет различные тактики поведения, движения, скорость, комплектацию, да и в целом, они различны.

[h1]Звук:[/h1]
По-поводу звука можно сказать одно - он превосходен. Звук как ни что другое должен передавать атмосферу в игре, особенно в играх данного жанра. Мрачный и давящий на сознание эмбиент, биение сердца, звуки окружения и монстров, все касающееся звука в игре сделано замечательно.

[h1]Графика:[/h1]
Что касается графики, она не вызывает нареканий, она проста и незамысловата, здесь нет современных технологий сглаживания и глобального затемнения, но графика в игре приятна, да и графическая составляющая игры наравне со звуком передает её атмосферу.

[h1]Итог:[/h1]
Процедурная генерация палуб корабля, отличный звук, хорошая графика, несколько видов противников и способов спастить, несколько концовок и довольно непростой геймплей, давящая атмосфера, которая заставит сикать в штанишки на протяжении всей игры, пока вас не сожрет оно...
Игру нельзя пройти... точнее это сделали лишь 5% от общего числа игравших в игру людей. Подумайте, сможете ли вы попасть в эти пять процентов... да и... оно вам надо?
Лучше не играйте, сбережете нервы.
Остальным - бегите [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/296710/] покупайте[/url].

10 из 10.

16503163.review:
This game could really use some difficulty levels, or better, an actual stealth system--that would be fantastic.

After playing on and off for a couple of hours, the weird and robotlike motion of the viewpoint character is getting to me and I've been killed repeatedly and almost instantly by walking into the wrong room or failing to escape--far enough--from a pop-out monster.

I've come across a number of notes that either hint--with very poor grammar--at some sort of evil in... wherever you are... or else discuss some routine thing that happened before everything went to custard. They don't do anything to advance a plot; I'm assuming that there isn't one. If there is, I'm not interested in knowing about it.

The rest of the game is walking from nearly-identical room to nearly-identical room until one of several poorly-animated and completely unrelated-looking critters eats my face. I wasn't sure whether to expect survival horror or what I'll call "running around powerless until you die or the game ends". It's definitely the second one.

The game doesn't appear to offer any form of weapon or even anything to slow down an evil thing coming for you. That feeling of helplessness could be either frightening or frustrating. In this case, it's frustrating. There's also very little cover, and there's no indication of whether you're successfully outrunning something pursuing you. Of course, if you stop and look, you're dead. That, or there's an extremely high chance that you'll come close to escaping, then accidentally flee into a room with something hideous waiting for you.

The audio suggests a weak attempt or two at letting you know *ahead of time* whether you should avoid a particular room or corridor, but it turns out to be largely useless. Without any music at all, you'd expect a little more work on the rest of the audio, right? It's essentially a small collection of monster screeches and a few door opening/closing sounds accompanied by what must be a world record for the largest number of broken steam pipes in any game ever.

I suspect that the authors were inspired by something like Outlast or Amnesia or what-have-you. Unfortunately, this is a poor imitation of those games.

With a few months' polish and some heavy audio work, this could have been or could eventually be a lot better. The procedurally generated layout is interesting, but apparently it only has a handful of room types to work with and an only slightly higher number of fixed or gatherable items to go in those rooms.

16437643.review:
Если Вы хотите острых ощущений, адреналина и немного безнадеги, то Монструм - игра для Вас. Если же Вы хотите игру с продуманным сюжетом, интересными персонажами и глубоким психологизмом, то проходите мимо. В данном случае мы имеем дело с игрой, в которой есть только завязка, но нет развития сюжета как такового, а только непосредственный процесс спасения. Зато монстры дадут в прямом смысле слова просраться своими неожиданными появлениями и некоторой непобедимостью.
Из плюсов у игры интересный сеттинг, запоминающиеся враги, вариативность развития событий и действующая способность Вас напугать, если только Вы не играете энное количество часов подряд.
Минусы - однообразность (бродишь по кораблю, прячешься от монстров, ищешь предметы, умираешь и всё заново), скука, которая наступает спустя минут 30 игры, отсутствие внятного объяснения происходящим событиям (из записок мало что можно почерпнуть) и, по моему мнению, откровенно завышенное превосходство игры над игроком (пройти до конца с учетом постоянно меняющихся уровней крайне сложно).

Итог: интересный по задумке хоррор, который доставит незабываемые впечатления при первых сеансах, но в дальнейшем начинает навевать скуку.

16429129.review:
All right, at first sight this might look like your average poorly made horror game with no story, you alone in a place and a monster wanting to hug you to death. Yeah, we have some of that basic formula.

However, this one is set on a procedurally generated derelict cargo ship, where you'll have 3 different means of escaping from one of the randomly picked 3 monsters currently present in the game. And I can assure you, it won't be easy. The monsters seem to have wallhacks at times, and the items needed to repair and use one of your escapes (a liferaft, an helicopter, a submarine) are randomly scattered across the ship, which is LARGE and easy to get lost in.

You'll need to survive long enough to find everything you need to escape using your smarts, your stealth, and your speed, should the need arise. You can run, you can create distractions, you can sneak, you can hide; whatever works at the moment.

Each monster has different abilities and characteristics, and while you'll need specific items to escape, you'll also find several misc items that will help you survive longer, creating light to see better, noises to distract the monster or being able to stun it for a few seconds, letting you escape a certain death.

While costing a fairly high amount of cash and not being completely bug free, other than suffering from poor performance in a few situations, it's completely worth a try. If your wallet is too light or you don't fully trust this game, just wait for major sales.

With this game you get the treat and the trick. With advanced AI, randomly generated rooms and items and high difficulty this game is certain to not become boring even after a while. And it will surprise you. Many times.

16377001.review:
Oh man. I just completely finished the game, and it's been thrilling. I've never felt such adrenaline finally completing the last win I needed to seal every achievement. 

For those contemplating purchasing, this game is honestly great. I've played my fair share of Amnesia, Damned, and many other indie horrors, and this one really puts the icing on the cake. There isn't any downtime of excitement, and it never gets boring. Each map is completely different (excluding the general places a ship would have, such as the engine room, bridge, etc.), with each room being randomly generated. Also, each item is placed in different locations, with some items far exceeding the quantity of others, and each monster is randomly chosen. My favorite part is finding out which monster you're going against, because that's when the real excitement starts. 

Though it's exciting, a lot of the excitement comes from the horror and suspense of each chase scene. You're able to hide in lockers, shoot flares at the monsters, and even die from falling. The spooks are very real. 

To the team of Monstrum and Junkfish, great job with the game, each win feels like an exciting victory, and I really enjoyed playing through. I can't wait until my next win!

16356888.review:
化け物と楽しく追いかけっこするゲームです。

【ストーリー】
主人公は突然謎の船で目覚める。ｸｫｸｫｱ…。
なぜここにいるのか、自分が何者なのか、何も覚えていない。
脱出方法を求めて船をさまよう主人公の前には謎の化け物が2匹。
果たして脱出することはできるのだろうか。

【システム】
2匹の化け物から逃げ回りながら、脱出に使うアイテムを集めていきます。
主人公は一切の戦闘手段を持ちませんが、化け物は音に敏感な性質をもつので、物を投げたりして音を立て、おびき寄せたりといった方法で逃げることができます。
もちろんロッカーなどに逃げ込むこともできます。化け物は耳がいい反面、目は悪いので、机の下に潜む程度でもスルーしてくれたりします。
船の内部構造やアイテム配置は毎回ランダム生成されるため、毎回スリルある展開を楽しむことができます。
脱出ルートは4種類あるようです。それぞれ必要なアイテムが異なります。

【イイところ】
とにかく怖いです。特に音の使い方が上手く、化け物のうめき声や足音には恐怖を駆り立てられます。
船内の環境音（パイプから噴き出る蒸気や謎のサイレンなど）もよくできています。
1プレイが短めなのでサクサクプレイできます。

【イマイチなところ】
マップのランダム生成とアイテムのランダム配置はあまり面白くないかなと思います。
リプレイ性の向上と、毎回新鮮なスリルをという狙いはわかりますが、ランダムすぎて攻略のために依って立つとっかかりがないため、とにかく総当たりでアイテム収集しなければならず、個人的には合いませんでした。

ランダム性には好き嫌いが出るかもしれませんが、怖さは折り紙つきなホラゲです。
とにかく怖いゲームを求める方にはおすすめです。

16150247.review:
From the reviews I was looking forward to a creepy tense survival horror experience. Good survival horror toys with you by using misdirection and engaging your imagination. Monstrum however is a jump scare slot machine with little cat and mouse and misdirection. Everything is telegraphed to you and is 1:1. You here thumping? Then you know the lava guy is around. You see the lights flicker? You know a ghost is near. See sacks on the wall? Be ready to be chased by a derivative monster. The game rules are very clear, which is good for a rogue like, but makes for a very dull horror experience. At no point did they achieve actual terror with me. The game never made me question my surroundings or my own senses, except for using the same texture on nearly every wall. 

I never once found myself coming across a narrative moment that made think "what's going on here?" Everything felt sterile. They even missed the opportunity to have the ship creak and the doors sway as the ship rocks against the waves. Or even have the ambient ship sounds change over time. Instead you're on what must be the absolutely most silent ship, ever. They never pulled the rug out from under me. They don't toy with you, which is the very meaning of "cat and mouse." Simply having something patroling after you is not cat and mouse, it's hide and go seek. Cat and mouse means toying with me, letting me escape only to appear around the very next corner, creating that "phew... OH MY GOD!" kind of moments. Instead it's just hide and go seek. If that's what you're into, this is for you. If you're looking for something that's going to try to get into your head  you might want to pass.

16089831.review:
Wander a dank ship for hours looking for duct-tape whilst one of three monsters chases you. 

The Brute, a dim witted giant lava-troll who will charge and bash down anything that gets between you and him, then close in for a nice warm cuddle. The Hunter, a spoopey, scurey slime skeleton who can slither through vents and snake along the floor, leaving behind his goopey mess from which he can teleport from at anytime. 

And a X-com alien.

Great fun. The cramped, dark atmosphere is perfect, and stays fresh with each playthrough, as the maze of corridors resets it layout everytime. The monsters are far more than a simple model change too, each one having different traits and gimicks. The Hunter for example is stealthy and agile, and his ability to pop out the vents and egg-sacks makes him a deadly suprise, but he's stopped easily in a chase by the ships doors due to his lack of strength. The brute however charges at the fastest pace of all three, and locked doors mean nothing to him. But he's loud and lacks any kind of stealth, and his low inteligence makes him easy to trick with noises and such.

It might lose it's charm after a good few playthrough's, but for the price Monstrum is a great little indie horror game.

16088319.review:
What do you do when you're stuck on a boat with no one left to turn to but yourself, while three evil creatures are after you? Hide in closets of course! Monstrum is a game developed and published by Team Junkfish. It's a procedurally generated survival horror game with roguelike elements. By forcing you to restart your campaign to escape forcing you to face a completely different monster every time you die, since the three main monsters in the game switch when you're killed. Making you come up with a new strategy every time you play. The only things that remain constant are the locations of the escape routes; the helicopter, submarine and life raft, all of which have different items you have to collect while avoiding being mauled by monsters. It is very likely you will be killed though, but dying is a big part of this game, so don't worry too much if you can't beat the game within your first hour of playing. If the achievements on Steam can be believed, not a lot of people have beaten this game.

The entirety of the game takes place in a boat, a particularly old one at that; all of the rooms are rusty and in varying states of decay. Obviously something happened, but your character has no idea because he has amnesia and has to piece together just how he got there and what happened on the boat. There are no cutscenes to introduce the story—the game just drops you in and lets you to figure it out. The player has the option of just running through the game without picking up a single piece of story and beating it. The story isn't conveyed as much as it is implied by the various pieces of paper scattered across the area telling you just what happened. While they do give you helpful hints, they aren't needed to complete the game. Following the story isn't required, all that's required is gathering up the items and not to be killed by one of the many beasts in the game. Think of it like a sadistic scavenger hunt, where if you don't find all of your items in time, your face gets melted off by a lava monster.

Each enemy's design is unique, ranging from the lava faced Brute, the purple-veined ethereal Fiend, and the gangly sharp limbed Hunter. They all have different styles of tracking you down and killing you whenever you do something important or if they just feel like it. The AI makes them attack at random times, so there could be a long period where you don't see them at all, only to suddenly hear them down the hallway. You have to run fast in order to escape into the safety of a locker, cupboard, or under a bed. If you aren't well hidden enough, they'll find you and rip you out of your supposed safety. This is why it's important to pay attention to where you're hiding, and if you have something in your hand that could alert the creatures of your presence, like a flashlight that's turned on towards the door.

[url=http://www.noobfeed.com/reviews/1144/monstrum]Full Review[/url]

16078596.review:
Two words describe this game better than any other horror game: replay value
And a third word would be: horror, as this game is a true prize-winner among other so-called horror games.
The ship is randomly generated, the monster is chosen from 3 monster types and you never know what to expect from this game. Every monster is different and has its own intelligence. There are  3 escape routes, each needing a few items scattered randomly across the ship.
Sadly, i must admit that i have never managed to finish the game. The AI is so great and difficult to overcome that this game actually proves to be a challenge and the atmosphere is so great that I have trouble sleeping at night (kidding, but i sometimes have trouble advancing through the game cause i am frightened and end up hiding in a locker).
10/10 one of the great horror games out there (except amnesia ofc)

16062735.review:
Over the years I have acquired a lot of Steam games, but rarely do I feel sufficiently motivated to write a review for a particular game. For Monstrum, I am more than willing to make an exception. Be warned, this is long, pretentious and tries to be more cerebral than my brain can handle, but fuck it, I love this game too much.

The premise: 

You are alone on a ship.
You need to get off the ship.
Something else is on the ship.
You don't know what it is.
You don't know where it is.
It. Is. Hunting. You.

Anyone who has played Slender, Outlast, Amnesia or any other screaming youtuber-bait knows the drill - darkness + beastie + orchestral stings = Not Another Generic Indie Horror Title amirite? Certainly I will not pretend that Monstrum is a title that pushes the genre's boundaries in any meaningful way; it is in essence a corridor crawler where you must find certain items to achieve a goal whilst avoiding a hostile entity that would like nothing more than to make you not be alive no more.

What Monstrum is, is an exemplary and noteworthy addition to the indie horror family, one that I feel stands alongside Amnesia in terms of achievement. It earns this accolade through its incredible mastery of two distinct elements that are absolutely intrinsic to the basic concept of horror, be it within video games or entertainment media in general.

The first element is Sound. Any horror film/game/show worth its salt has at least a basic understanding that, while Sight is the sense that is the easiest to use to convey the imagination of the creator of the film/game/show, Sound is the ultimate doorway into the imagination of the viewer/player themselves. Sound can paint pictures, it can control emotions, and it can create POSSIBILITIES. In horror, Sight is the opening of Schroedinger's Box. In horror, Sound IS Schroedinger's Box. With Sound, there are no constants, only variables. And amongst those variables, horror crawls and chitters.

In Monstrum, as you travel around the claustrophobic corridors and gantries of the ship, ignorant of the location of your nemesis, things can seem quiet in a very stark, relative way. But Monstrum is not quiet. Wherever you go, you are beset by Sound, in the form of groaning doors, hissing pipes, humming electronics, crashing waves and hostile camera alarms. The ambient Sound is Monstrum is spectacular, creating a sense of sickening dread that I have only felt in a number of games that I can count on two fingers. Unusually, the most notable of these is the Sound that you as the player will create. Every step you take clangs and echoes through like ship like a demented church bell, every door you open screeches and wails like a titanium newborn. In terms of Sound, the actions that you as a player take create such a hideous, crunching contrast with the perceived silence that you will curse every door, every drawer, every step as you fight the urge to run before the Creature comes to investigate all the noise you're making.

I'm not even going to mention the noises the Creature makes as it closes in on you. You can buy the game if you want a taste of that.

The second horror element that Monstrum, in my opinion, blows out of the park, is The Unknown. Historically, one of the best examples of the use of The Unknown is of course Lovecraftian horror, and the cosmicism principle that we are an infinitely insignificant species, at the non-existent mercy of beings, entities or powers infinitely greater than ourselves. This premise is tapped into by a significant number of video games, notably Call of Cthulu, Alone in The Dark (THE ORIGINAL ALONE IN THE DARK, LET ME BE CLEAR), Slender and even Mass Effect to an extent. Fear of The Unknown is an ancient, biological instinct, pervading millions of years of evolution, death, predation and cowering in the dark. It teaches us that inside Schroedinger's Box, there may not be a cat at all - there may simply be teeth, teeth that allow us to scream for half a second before clamping over our throat.

The ship in Monstrum is randomly generated each time you play. Every time you start a new game, once-familiar corridors, corners and entrances will evaporate, replaced with a new, alien configuration. Key items required to escape from the ship will move around like mischievous imps with every playthrough, taunting you with their absence. This flawless use of The Unknown means that in Monstrum, there is no real strategy guide, no Youtube walkthrough, and certainly no map. The only guide you will have is the one in your mind - the one you hastily scribble inside your head as you traverse new doors, new passages, new threats. This is where Monstrum achieves - no matter how many times you play, you cannot know all. No matter how many times you play......The Unknown will be there with you.

Finally, we come to it. Your Nemesis. The Creatures themselves. Horror itself demands an antagonist, and Monstrum delivers not one, but three. Each time you play, the game will randomly select one of three completely different Creatures to come play with you. No spoilers, buy the game. All you need to know is that when you start a new game YOU DO NOT KNOW WHICH CREATURE IS ON THE SHIP WITH YOU. It is difficult to describe the feeling this elicits within me every time I open that first door, and I suspect that is because it is a feeling that I have rarely felt, perhaps have NEVER felt. It is The Unknown, boiled to purity and soaked into my soul. I don't know where I am. I don't know where it is. God help me, I don't know what it is.

Monstrum unlocks the power of random/procedural generation in video games in a way that is blisteringly brilliant, a way that I cannot adequately intone. There are some minor issues with this game, but I cannot even begin to summon the wherewithal to mention them. Monstrum's use of Sound is devastating to the nerves, its cloying, rusty graphics a steroid to my wide, glistening eyes. This is indie horror.

Buy it.

16034398.review:
I know a lot of people like this game and believe me, it is visually appealing and the atmosphere is great. In fact the first bit of time you spend playing the game is amazing. The reason I don't recommend this game though is that after a bit you start to realize that the AI is absolutely terrible. The hunter is supposed to be able to hunt you down with a scent trail you leave and the longer you stay in an area the more noticeable it is. This does not happen. In fact, unless you start running around in circles jumping up and down and turning your flashlight on and off (or set off a camera and a door HAPPENS to be in their way) the monsters almost NEVER enter any rooms besides the main hallways and what not. When they do enter, as long as you are in a locker and they did not directly see you enter the locker you are almost guaranteed to be safe. I have never been killed while in a locker. Once while the hunter was in the room with me I ran around in circles in the locker and turned my flashlight on and off and the hunter acted like it didn't notice anything and started walking out of the room and when I saw this I opened the locker door while it was still in the room and it gave zero shits and walked out and disappeared. Also the monsters do not really 'hunt' you, more they just 'happen' to appear in the same areas of the ship as you occaisionally. Overall the AI could use a bit of an overhaul. I will happily change my review if they improve the AI.

EDIT: Thank you team junkfish for the reply, I look forward to seeing what you can do if possible.

EDIT 2: I read the bit on the hunter from the wiki here: http://themonstrum.wikia.com/wiki/The_Hunter
I would check the other monsters on the wikis as well for inaccuracies as a fair amount of them make pretty bold claims.

16010068.review:
Monstrum kombinuje to nejlepší, co dnešní hororovky nabízí - hutnou atmosféru, strach, skvělou kombinaci světla a stínů, výborné zpracování a jednoduché ovládání, to vše za velmi příjemnou cenu.

První hodinku hraní strávíte spíše tím, že se budete krčit pod prvním stolem, na který narazíte, poslouchat podivné zvuky linoucí se zřejmě z místnosti hned vedle vás a budete se proklínat, že jste si tuhle hru vůbec zapnuli. Po namluvení si, že je to vlastně jen hra, se vydáte prozkoumávat prostory zatím neznámého plavidla. Loď je vcelku obrovská a je skoro nemožné se v ní dokonale orientovat. Postupem času si už sice budete pamatovat hlavní záchytné body ve formě trupu lodi, můstku nebo strojovny, pořád ale můžete vlézt někam, kde budete dlouhé minuty ztraceni.

Ačkoli hra nemá víceméně žádný příběh - ten se lehce rýsuje jen na pozadí ve formě nalezených lístečků od kamarádů, kteří vám ale můžou být stejně šumák, protože už zřejmě zemřeli bolestivou smrtí - tak vám zabere dlouhé hodiny, než hru vůbec dohrajete, jestli vůbec. Vaším cílem je totiž najít co nejrychleji únikovou cestu a snažit se přitom nenarazit na děsivé monstrum, které si vás okamžitě naporcuje k večeři. Tahle hra velice dobře využívá survival prvky, takže vaše konfrontace s monstrem vyústí v okamžitou smrt a můžete začít znovu. Proto je opravdu třeba vnímat jakékoli zvuky a změny na palubě. Občas vám monstrum dá malou šanci na útěk, ale zbytečně si tím jen prodlužujete vaše trápení.

Postupem času zjistíte, že i na ono monstrum se dá vymyslet hafo strategií. Horší ale je, že ve hře jsou monstra rovnou tři, z nichž náhodně dostanete na každou hru jedno, takže se může také stát, že než vůbec zjistíte, proti komu stojíte, bude už krapet pozdě.

To samé platí také pro únikové cesty, které nestačí jenom najít, ale také opravit nebo zprovoznit. K tomu všemu vám ve hře poslouží veliká řada předmětů, z nichž ty nejdůležitější jsou samozřejmě velice vzácné. Předměty se po lodi spawnují náhodně, takže nemá smysl si dělat roztřesenou rukou poznámky, kde jste předtím co našli.

Doporučuji hrát hru pouze v noci, a to nejen kvůli zážitku. Ke hraní ve tmě je prostě třeba hrát ve tmě. :)

Hra vydrží spousty hodin a přesně daná herní doba neexistuje. Jednoduše si nedáte pokoj, dokud z lodi neuniknete, a na to si pár večerů rozhodně připravte. Znovuhratelnost je stoprocentní.

HODNOCENÍ: 8/10

16003176.review:
I played this game for a short time. But for every single minute of that time my heart was pounding and muscles were tense! This game is the mother of all recent horror games.
The premise is simple: escape from a ship. On the way, you can collect various notes trying to uncover what happened on the ship. But it just happens that there is a monster on the ship that is very VERY HUNGRY.
The game mechanics is simple. You can collect various items (e.g., flash lights, switches) and use them where needed to power something, open doors or get some additional light. The level of interactivity is pretty much on the Amnesia level. At least, so far I have not figure out any way to fend off the monster.
What makes this game unique is that if you die (aka became late night dinner for the monster) then it is game over. Not only you will have to start from the very beginning, but also things will be very different during new playthrough due to random mechanics in the game. Even the monster can be different! YAY! It is not like I have not been horrified enough by the same damn monster. Needless to say that the game has a great atmosphere in terms of both visuals and sound effects. I was constantly spooked by sudden screeching noises typical to old ships while nervously staring at a dark patch of corridor. Have I mentioned adaptive elements in the game music or how I died the last time? I was staring at dark hall when a tense music suddenly switched on. I immediately knew that the monster is on to me and begun running away in panic only to fall through a hole in a container with no way to escape. The next second the monster was falling through the very same hall right into my face. Yes, the music made me panic and lead to my death.
In short, this is quite a good horror game with reasonable replay value well worth its price tag. Finally, it runs quite decently on medium settings on my 4-years old laptop.

15999300.review:
first off i want to say i highly recommend this game even if this review sounds a little weird. my only complaint to the game is i dont think it should be roguelike. like permadeath is a good idea and it should wipe your saves in my opinion. because as it stands right now trying to repair an escape method is like a good 2 hours of wandering the ship if your quick. so id like to save once in a while so i could like leave and go to work and stuff. but other than that the game is great. my favorite experiences to date so far was.  

playthrough 1. i started off the game trying to gather my bearings and i just started sprinting and making noise all over the place. i soon booked it to a staircase and found my way onto the deck of the ship. i came across a deflated liferaft, i was all like "damn now i gotta run and find some tape and some other things to fix this. while reading my journal and trying to figure out what objects i was looking for, a flying translucent wraith grabbed me from behind and preceeded to molest my body to death.
playthrough 2. my friend took over for a turn and slowly walked down the hallway to find what were the shower rooms. after hearing a noise of a door opening somewhere in the ship my friend decided to hide in the shower for a good 5 minutes waiting for his utter death, while he was frozen in fear i told him to leave and do something in the game because who wants to watch someone hide forever. slowly after hearing something getting nearer he ran to another small room and hid inside a cupboard. after a minute or two of hiding he decided to leave the cupboard and go for the door to leave. and as he opens the door a giant flaming gasmask wearing S.O.B. grabs him and breaks his neck.
playthrough 3. by this point i was just like man lets try and get caught. so i ran to one room and found a chair i could move on the floor. for over 10 minutes i sat in this room throwing this chair around making noise and throwing my belongings on the ground. by this point i was like maybe they cant hear this so i opened the door and ran out to the hallway. i then ran up and down the hallway yelling at my computer screen COME AND GET ME!!! for about 30 seconds i ran up and down the hallway and then stopped and brought my attention to a light at the end of the hallway. in the light was  a fire extinguisher. like a madman on steroids i ran for this fire extinguisher at the end of the hall. i picked it up and instantaneously used the entire thing up in an attempt to make more noise. IT WORKED! :D i saw the red light of the flameman aka johnny storm coming down the stairs. the man then screamed at me and proceeded to chase me. like a scared baby i ran for my life to the room with the chair, locked the door, hid in a locker, and waited. he blew through the door with ease so i guess he ignores locks. and he ran up to the locker i was hiding in and stared me down through the crack. i could see it in his eyes, he was saying to me " Stop making noise down here you bastard or ill be back" i took this warning and i did what any sane person would do... i waited til he left the room and then left my hiding spot and chased him down i then ran straight into him at the end of the hallway. needless to say he won this game of chicken and probably feasted on my remains or whatever they do with the bodies of these poor ppl who are left to wander this ship. 

in all though the game is great. like when your actually trying not to get caught and you see something bust out of a vent and come after you stuff like that is crazy. i highly reccomend the game. 11/10 would bang a chair around again.

15998759.review:
(First of all, sorry I know my english is not perfect :D)

Ok, in all honesty I would not describe this game as thaaaaaat scary.  Sure, the first 3 games, where you encounter the monsters for the first time, are freaking scary. No map, no idea where to go or what to do, no idea what is trying to kill you. But once you have like lets say 6 games behind you, that fear is mostly gone, since you know more or less what to do and how the monsters more or less behave. Dose this make it a bad game? Absolutely not!

Even if it mostly stops to be scary after a few playthroughs, it is still a very tens, hard and fun game.  Permadeath, randomly generated levels for each playthrough, 3 monsters which are very different from another (and who knows, maybe even more in the future) and traps/obstacles to make your life a little harder. The map is very much like a maze and forces u to vaguely memorize it, since you don´t want to end up in a dead end when you are running away (and  you are going to be running a lot). Many times you are stuck in a room and you don´t have the guts to open the door because the monster might be right behind the door, since u know it is somewhere near by. Up till now i did only once almost manage to beat the game, but I panicked, ran the wrong direction into a dead end, tried hiding under a bed and well ... you can guess the rest probably.

All in all I would definitely recommend this game and is a musthave once you find it on 50 or 75% sale (if u like this sort of games). And by the way, the fact that this game dose not really scare me, is just a personal thing. Maybe it can scare you for much longer then me :) .

15919800.review:
Horror is my favorite game genre because it invokes so much emotion.  Unlike a horror movie, if there is something you don't like you can't just look away and pretend the threat isn't there.  In a horror video game you need to act or else you will die.  This is true for any horror game, but I think it is the most true for Monstrum.  Why?  Well for a few big reasons:

1)  The environment is random every time you play.  Because of this, you feel lost every time and you need to build an incredibly vague map in your head on where you have already been and where you need to go next.  It's like the worst scavenger hunt you can imagine yourself being in.  It's a frickin nightmare.

2)  The monster is chosen randomly each time.  The beginning of each new game is always terrifying because you have no idea what is after you until it gets close.  Each monster is terrifying in it's own way.  They are either loud and terrifying to look at, or really fast and hard to see.  Each monster is scary in their own unique way, making each experience fresh.   When you get seen you need to make extremely quick decisions on where and when you should hide.

3)  The monsters don't f**k around.  You have to run as soon as they see you.  LIKE RIGHT WHEN IT HAPPENS you better have a finger on the shift key and hauling ass out of there.

Basically, this game takes what is consistently scary (the unknown)  and puts it into every aspect of the game.  Unknown layout, unknown item placement, and unknown enemy and turns it into a great experience.  I still have yet to beat the game after all this time, and I actually love that about it.  It should be this hard.  It should make you feel like the terror is greater than your courage.  

The terror is smarter than you.  The terror is better than you.  But you are going to do everything you can to fight it and escape.

This is the best horror game on Steam hands down and well worth the price.  Get it.
